"""
AITA Left my kid in the school and waited in the parking lot to scare him:
Left my kid in the school and waited in the parking lot to scare him:

8 year old kid. Has parent teacher conferences. Prior the the conferences he is freaking out about something (to my wife while I'm not there). During the conferences he gets a less than stellar report. He has good grades and all, but a lot of shouting/acting up in class. So after the conference he wants to buy a book from the library book store. My wife hesitates, and I drop a firm "No". He starts to get huffy and says hes going into the library book fair anyways, which he does.

I tell my wife lets just keep walking. So we walk out to the car, I put the three younger kids in, and my wife takes them home. She thinks I am going back in to get him. I stay in my car, which is in direct view of the exit of the school. I wait for him to come out which happens in about 20 minutes.

He comes out in a panic, crying, thinking we left him.

My wife is angry that I did not go into the school to get him, and that I instead led him to believe that we left him at the school.

I will update with any follow up/ or clarifying answers.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The scenario involves leaving their 8-year-old kid at school during a library book fair after the kid was already upset. The parents had parent-teacher conferences, and the kid was misbehaving in class. After the conference, the kid wanted to buy a book, but the dad said no. The kid went into the library book fair anyway, and the parents left, thinking the dad would go back to get him. But he didn't; he waited in the parking lot and let the kid come out alone. The kid ended up panicking and crying, thinking they had left him.

So the main issue here is whether the dad was wrong to stay in the car instead of going in to get the kid. The user thinks the author is in the wrong. Let me break it down.

First, the kid was already upset and had a less than stellar report. The dad's firm "No" probably made the kid more upset, leading him to go to the library book fair. The dad then didn't follow through on his intention to go get the kid, as his wife thought he would. Instead, he waited in the parking lot. The kid came out crying, thinking he was abandoned. The wife is angry because she thought the dad was going to get him.

From a child's perspective, being left without explanation, especially when already upset, can be traumatic. Even if the dad intended to wait, the child didn't know that. The dad's action of staying in the car and not going in might be seen as neglectful or emotionally manipulative. The kid's panic suggests that the dad's actions were harmful, even if the intention was to teach a lesson. 

The dad's reasoning might be that he wanted to teach the child a lesson for not listening, but the method used was leaving the child alone, which could be considered an emotional or psychological punishment. This might be crossing a line, especially with an 8-year-old who might not understand the situation. 

The wife's anger is justified because she thought the dad would go back, and he didn't. The dad's decision to stay in the car and wait for the kid to come out could be seen as abandoning the child, even temporarily. The child's crying and panic are a direct result of that decision. 

In terms of responsibility, parents have a duty to ensure their child's safety and emotional well-being. Leaving a child alone in a potentially stressful situation, even if it's just in the school, could be considered neglectful. The dad didn't go in, even though he had the opportunity to do so, and that might have been a mistake. 

So, putting it all together, the dad's actions led to the child being frightened and upset. Even if the intention was to discipline, the method was inappropriate. Therefore, the author is in the wrong. The answer should be A.
